title-group.article-title: Re: Karsidag S, Akcal A, Sahin S, et al. Neurophysiological and morphological responses to treatment with acetyl-l-carnitine in a sciatic nerve injury model: preliminary data. J Hand Surg Eur. 2012, 37: 529–536

contrib-group.aff: Shiraz University of Medical Sciences, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Shahid Chamran Hospital, Shiraz, Iran

permissions.copyright-holder: The British Society for Surgery of the Hand

body.p: I read with great interest the article by Karsidag and colleagues. This work showed that acetyl-l-carnitine can enhance nerve regeneration in nerve repair. I would like to complete the discussion of Karsidag and colleagues by introducing a major route through which acetyl-l-carnitine could promote regeneration.

After nerve repair many factors are important to enhance regeneration. Mitochondrial function in a Schwann cell is essential for maintenance of axonal survival and normal peripheral nerve function (Viader et al., 2011). Also, Na/K ATPase acts as a major adhesion molecule in a distal nerve segment to promote progression of peripheral nerve regeneration (Kawai et al., 1997).

Acetyl-l-carnitine is an acetylated derivative of carnitine. It is an endogenous substance present in the nervous tissue. Acetyl-l-carnitine is known, not only to promote the transport of cytosolic long-chain fatty acids into mitochondria for b-oxidation, thereby providing mitochondrial functional energy, but also, has an increased production effect on the Na+/- K+_ATPase (Kotil et al., 2007; Sima et al., 1996) . Therefore, these important mechanisms should be borne in mind as the major mechanisms for acetyl-l-carnitine – reduced regeneration in acute nerve repair.
